report_title: Cookie, Cracker & Pasta Production in the US
executive_summary: Cookie, cracker and pasta producers see stable demand for products since they are well-established as part of consumers' diets, although changing trends have prompted these producers to innovate new products in recent years. Nonetheless, diets that cut out carbohydrates and wheat-based goods have stifled growth significantly. Conversely, the rise of popular cooking TV shows and other content has made younger generations expansively purchase their pasta, baking mixes and dough to prepare meals and desserts at home. Although boosted disposable income through the end of 2023 has allowed consumers to upgrade to more premium brands and varieties, it has also allowed consumers to purchase a broader range of alternative products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: As More People Demand Healthier Food Options, Product Mix Shifts
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Some cookie, cracker and pasta producers have reformulated products, while others have introduced healthier and more nutritious brand extensions to drive demand for their goods. Consumers have responded positively to these new products, preventing a more serious decline in industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: POSITIVE DEMAND TRENDS AS THE ECONOMY GROWS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cookie, cracker and pasta consumption typically doesn't drop during economic downturns, and per capita disposable income has inched up, boosting consumption of these food items across all demographics. Producers of cookies, crackers and pasta weathered the economic downturn during COVID-19; as more consumers spent time at home, consumption surged because of the typical inexpensive cost of such foods. Also, as consumers limited trips to the grocery store, stockpiling these shelf-stable products became popular.

Cookie, cracker and pasta producers have boosted sales directly to retailers through the expanded use of online ordering systems. Larger industry producers boosted their scale to provide a greater range of options to downstream customers, including healthier alternatives. For example, in 2018, the Campbell Soup Company acquired Snyder's-Lance, Inc, the second-largest producer of salty snacks in the United States.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SNACKING WILL BE ON THE RISE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As people continue returning in person to work and consumer lives become even busier, they will eat more snacks, including cookies and crackers. Time-strapped consumers will also find convenience in cooking meals requiring low preparation, like pasta.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: EXPANDING DESIRE FOR PREMIUM GOODS WILL SUPPORT DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although cookie, cracker and pasta products are staples for consumers, producer performance is still influenced by disposable income levels. Boosted per capita disposable income will allow consumers to purchase branded and premium products, which are more expensive than generic brands.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: BOOMING INNOVATION ENCOURAGES DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cookie, cracker and pasta producers will continue innovating and introducing healthier brand extensions, including gluten-free options. Manufacturers will also benefit from growing international demand for organic, nutrient-enhanced pasta, cookies and crackers.

industry_definition: Cookie, cracker and pasta producers make cookies, crackers and dry pasta from purchased ingredients, like flour, sugar, salt, seasoning, emulsifiers, flavorings, syrups, preservatives, food acids and gluten.
key_trends: Cookie, cracker and pasta producers benefit from relatively steady demand due to the nondiscretionary nature of food. More substitute snacking items and baked goods can be purchased at grocery stores.

US households may turn away from imported pasta and cookies from countries such as Italy, as cookie, cracker and pasta producers manufacture more premium products, including those that appeal to health-conscious consumers.
The industry faces substantial public policy aimed at protecting consumers' health and well-being.
Cookie, cracker and pasta producers do not receive direct assistance from the government in the form of import tariffs, but tariffs on imported products shield pasta manufacturers.
The cookies, wafers and ice cream cones segment's share of revenue surged despite growing health concerns among Americans, while crackers and biscuits contracted.
Producers that locate near key markets are at an advantage.
Innovation is vital for success in the commercial business sector.
Brand equity keeps consumers loyal to their preferred cookies, crackers and pasta. Recognizable cookie, cracker and pasta brands are associated with consistent ingredients and taste.
Input costs aren't easy to predict and often eat away at profit. Still, companies have passed down some rising costs to downstream markets.
Large companies attain an above-average profit. Manufacturers such as Kellogg's and Campbell's can minimize per-unit manufacturing costs through scale.

market_segmentation.segment: Supermarkets, convenience stores, gas stations and grocery stores
market_segmentation.segment_description: Retail stores include supermarkets, grocery stores, gas stations and convenience stores. Mass merchandisers, like Target and Walmart, have expanded their grocery product selection, helping boost this market segment's performance.
Warehouse clubs and supercenters, like Walmart, include large stores that retail a general line of grocery products and merchandise items.
Grocery wholesalers purchase cookies, crackers and pasta from manufacturers and distribute them in bulk to supermarkets, mass merchandisers, convenience stores and food service customers.

products_and_services.product_description: Products in this segment include prepared flour and dough mix used by downstream food producers and households to make prepared foods like bread and bakery products, pizza and cake.
A variety of cookies and crackers comprise this segment, including new, healthier varieties, like gluten-free chocolate chip cookies.
The dry pasta segment includes plain and packaged dry pasta products sold separately or packaged with other ingredients such as seasonings, flavorings and additives.
A variety of crackers and biscuits including artisan and gluten-free options.
Other industry products refer to the other products made with dough, batter and purchased flour, including frozen mixes. This product segment accounts for less than 5.0% of total revenue.

tier_1_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US
Fruit & Nut Farming in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Dairy Product Production in the US
tier_1_buyers: Soft Drink, Baked Goods & Other Grocery Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Brand equity keeps consumers loyal to their preferred cookies, crackers and pasta. Recognizable cookie, cracker and pasta brands are associated with consistent ingredients and taste.
Input costs aren't easy to predict and often eat away at profit.
As the economy strengthens, household disposable income will expand.
Most industry products contain wheat and, thus, are susceptible to swings in demand depending on consumer preferences.
Manufacturers have introduced a variety of healthier and nutritious varieties of cookies, crackers and pasta in recent years.
The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its trading partners.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Proximity to end markets allow manufacturers to take advantage of lower transport and distribution costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: While Imports Remain Regional, New Avenues Will Widen Over the Coming Years
international_trade_points.trade_description: The proximity and favorable trade environment under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement encourage high import penetration from Canada and Mexico.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE LOW-VALUE NATURE OF COOKIES, CRACKERS AND PASTA LIMITS EXPORTS
international_trade_points.trade_description: The low value of cookies, crackers and pasta makes them relatively expensive to transport.

international_trade_points.trade_title: THE STRENGTHENING US DOLLAR LIMITS OPPORTUNITIES ABROAD
international_trade_points.trade_description: The strength of the US dollar limits export opportunities.

business_locations.location_description: California, which resides in the West, houses the most cookie, cracker and pasta producers out of all states in the United States.
The Mid-Atlantic region is home to some of the biggest and most affluent cities in the United States.
Florida which resides in the Southeast has a large population, providing a large consumer base for cookie, cracker and pasta producers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA regulates the Cookie, Cracker and Pasta Production industry.
OSHA is responsible for enforcing safety and health legislation in the United States.
The EPA and state governments enforce environmental regulations.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports have surged through the end of 2023.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Cookie, cracker and pasta producers typically provide a wide array of products.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility impacted profit margins through the end of 2023?
FAQs.answer: The price of key inputs like wheat and sugar have fluctuated through the end of 2023.
